prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Our expected source parameters for G31.41+0.31 are taken from Beltran et al. (2005). The peak continuum flux density is 4.4 Jy which is derived using 1.4 mm continuum observations from the PdBI. Our peak line flux density is 0.00476 Jy, which is the peak flux for the weakest methyl formate (H13COOCH3 18(6,12)-17(6,11)) line we have detected in this object. We assume a line width of 13 MHz, which is the line width of the 18(8,10)-17(8,9) vt=1 transition of methyl formate, detected with the PdBI in this hot core. We wish to reach an angular resolution with these observations of 0.2'' in order to probe deep within the hot core and accurately derive temperature and density conditions. We have measured the largest angular size in our source to be 4'' based on maps of CH3CN (Fig. 1 of the science justification). We request a sensitivity of 0.00016 Jy, which will give us a S/N of 30 for our weakest line. This will allow us to detect methyl formate transitions which are weaker than our current detected weakest line. We have determined our 4 basebands to centre on 4 key transitions of both methyl formate vt=1 and glycolaldehyde (220.258 GHz, 222.372 MHz, 235.311 and 237.220 MHz. Within our 1875 MHz bandwidth in each of these basebands we expect to detect >20 transitions of methyl formate, >10 transitions of glycolaldehyde and > 10 transitions of methyl cyanide. All of these transitions probe energy levels from ~100 K - 1200 K and are well seperated. We request a total observation time of 29.29 mins to achieve this science goal with this technical specification for G31.41+0.31, including calibration and additional overheads.

Our expected source parameters for G24.78+0.08 are taken from Beltran et al. (2005). The peak continuum flux density is 0.1 Jy which is derived using 1.4 mm continuum observations from the PdBI for the weakest detected hot core in this star forming region. Our peak line flux density is 0.00238 Jy, which is the peak flux for the weakest methyl formate (HCOOCH3 vt=1 18(8,10)-17(8,9)) line we have detected in this object. We assume a line width of 15 MHz, which is the line width of the 18(8,10)-17(8,9) vt=1 transition of methyl formate, detected with the PdBI in this hot core. We wish to reach an angular resolution with these observations of 0.2'' in order to probe deep within the hot core and accurately derive temperature and density conditions. We have measured the largest angular size in our source to be 4'' based on maps of CH3CN (Fig. 1 of the science justification). We request a sensitivity of 0.00008 Jy, in order to detect transitions of methyl formate which are weaker than our current detected weakest line. We have determined our 4 basebands to centre on 4 key transitions of both methyl formate vt=1 and glycolaldehyde (220.258 GHz, 222.372 MHz, 235.311 and 237.220 MHz. Within our 1875 MHz bandwidth in each of these basebands we expect to detect >20 transitions of methyl formate, >10 transitions of glycolaldehyde and > 10 transitions of methyl cyanide. All of these transitions probe energy levels from ~100 K - 1200 K and are well seperated. We request a total observation time of 39.63 mins to achieve this science goal with this technical specification for G24.78+0.08, including calibration and additional overheads.

Our expected source parameters for G29.96-0.02 are taken from Beltran et al. (2011). The peak continuum flux density is 0.83 Jy which is derived using 1.4 mm continuum observations from the PdBI. Our peak line flux density is 0.00159 Jy, which is determined for the weakest line of methyl formate (HCOOCH3 vt=1 18(8,10)-17(8,9)) that we detect in our previous observations. We assume a line width of 12 MHz, which is the line width of the 18(8,10)-17(8,9) vt=1 transition of methyl formate, detected with the PdBI in this hot core. We wish to reach an angular resolution with these observations of 0.2'' in order to probe deep within the hot core and accurately derive temperature and density conditions. We have measured the largest angular size in our source to be 4'' based on maps of CH3CN (Fig. 1 of the science justification). We request a sensitivty of 0.00008 Jy, which would allow us to detect lines weaker than our current detected weakest line, but requiring a resonable integration time. We have determined our 4 basebands to centre on 4 key transitions of both methyl formate vt=1 and glycolaldehyde (220.258 GHz, 222.372 MHz, 235.311 and 237.220 MHz. Within our 1875 MHz bandwidth in each of these basebands we expect to detect >20 transitions of methyl formate, >10 transitions of glycolaldehyde and > 10 transitions of methyl cyanide. All of these transitions probe energy levels from ~100 K - 1200 K and are well seperated. We request a total observation time of 39.76 mins to achieve this science goal with this technical specification for G29.96-0.02, including calibration and additional overheads.

Our expected source parameters for Iras 17233-3606 are taken from Leurini et al. (2013). The peak continuum flux density is 18 mJy which is derived using 1.3 mm continuum observations from the SMA. Our peak line flux density is 0.00476 Jy, which is determined for the weakest line of methyl formate (HCOOCH3 vt=1 18(10,9)-17(10,8)) that we detect in our previous observations. We assume a line width of 10 MHz, which is the line width of the 18(8,10)-17(8,9) vt=1 transition of methyl formate, detected with the PdBI in this hot core. We wish to reach an angular resolution with these observations of 0.2'' in order to probe deep within the hot core and accurately derive temperature and density conditions. We have measured the largest angular size in our source to be 4'' based on maps of CH3CN (Fig. 1 of the science justification). We request a sensitivty of 0.00032 Jy, which would allow us to detect our current weakest line to a S/N ratio of ~15. This will allow us to detect far weaker transitions of methyl formate that we have previously detected. We have determined our 4 basebands to centre on 4 key transitions of both methyl formate vt=1 and glycolaldehyde (220.258 GHz, 222.372 MHz, 235.311 and 237.220 MHz. Within our 1875 MHz bandwidth in each of these basebands we expect to detect >20 transitions of methyl formate, >10 transitions of glycolaldehyde and > 10 transitions of methyl cyanide. All of these transitions probe energy levels from ~100 K - 1200 K and are well seperated. We request a total observation time of 29.13 mins to achieve this science goal with this technical specification for Iras 17233-3606, including calibration and additional overheads.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We wish to use the enhanced spatial resolution capabilities of ALMA to probe deep into the ultra compact centres within hot cores, where massive stars are forming. By detecting several bright, well-separated transitions of methyl formate (HCOOCH3) and glycolaldehyde (CH2OHCHO) we will unveil the densest, most compact regions. In particular we will focus on the excited transitions of methyl formate (vt=1), which we have previsouly observed to trace compact regions within hot cores.
